entry.title: Re: Time Based Cost and Revenue Recognition
entry.content:
Hi @KP_2025 ,
You can achieve uniform monthly recognition of both revenue (USD‚ÄØ100) and cost (USD‚ÄØ50) in SAP On‚ÄëPremises/Private Cloud by using time‚Äëbased revenue recognition methods such as ‚ÄúPeriodic Service‚Äù or ‚ÄúTime‚ÄëBased (Method 10)‚Äù in SAP Revenue Accounting and Reporting (RAR). These methods allow you to spread both revenue and planned costs evenly across the contract term rather than recognizing them upfront.
Configure Method 10 (Time‚ÄëBased Revenue Recognition) in SAP RAR or PS with a periodic billing plan. This will automatically recognize USD‚ÄØ100 revenue and USD‚ÄØ50 cost per month across the 12‚Äëmonth contract, matching your business requirement.

You can do following as mentioned below.

Billing Plan + Revenue Recognition Key
Create a yearly contract with a billing plan of 12 monthly periods.
Assign a time‚Äëbased revenue recognition key (Method 10).
Planned costs (USD‚ÄØ600) can be distributed using cost object planning so that USD‚ÄØ50 is recognized monthly.

Manual Deferral/Accrual
If no suitable key exists, you can post manual accruals/deferrals each month for revenue and cost.
This is less automated but ensures compliance.

entry.title: Re: How to track stock by pack size (5/25/50kg) with one...
entry.content:
Hello @FaisalMaayeh 

Thank you for your question

I understand your valid concern. In public cloud, the decision mainly depends on the question if you need the system to distinguish stock by pack size or is your pack size only a selling and picking convenience?

1. You can keep one material number and still sell in different pack sizes by using:

  • Base uoM for your inventory valuation and to keep stock
  • Alternative units of measure for selling and operational entry, which could be BAG5, BAG25 or BAG50.
  • Packing instructions and packing proposals so your warehouse can either pack pallets or carton and create handling units at a designated level, not per a single . See Automatic Packing ‚Äì Packing with Packing Instructions for more details.

However, if you keep one material and do not use split valuation, batch as a separation method, then the system generally does not know which pack sizes you physically have. That would mean that availability and allocation by pack size is not reliably supported just with unit conversions. So, if you must distinguish your pack size, my recommended best practice is usually to:

  • Separate materials per pack size or
  • You keep one material but use separation methods like split valuation or batch.

2. On your second question if HU management is meant for individual bags, the simple answer is NO. It is rather intended to track packed logistics units such as pallets, cartons, handling units used for storage and movement. Basically saying it can technically model any small units you wish to have but doing one HU per bag will explode HU volume and is not a recommended design. See Handling Units in Cloud Processes for more details.

3. There are some best practices you may consider:

First one is to use one material and maintain:

  • Base UoM =KG
  • Alternative UoMs for selling (BAG5=5KG; BAG25=25KG & BAG50=50KG)
  • Use Warehouse packing automation to:
    • Maintain packing instructions to propose realistic Hus on pallet level
    • Let the system create Hus when you receive, putaway, pick or pack based on those instructions.

That gives you one material, realistic HU counts and clean operational packing.

Second one is (if you must distinguish your pack size in stock) to:

  • Separate materials by pack size or keep one material and keep your separation method
  • Consider using batch separation by pack size only if your business process and governance support it (I don‚Äôt recommend this but I have seen it done)

To summarise:

One material, alternative UoM and packing instructions for pallet level HU will result in same cost and no need to separate stock by pack size.

One material without separation is risky if you need stock and ATP by pack size. Ensure to use separate materials or keep a separation method.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Part 2 I9 Not Routing to Corporate Representative for...
entry.content:
@Melissa_S Below is epected flow of remote hire in ONB2.0 product.

1.The remote hire‚Äôs record will appear in the I-9 section 2 tile and does not indicate it is a remote hire, at a glance. The corporate representative will need to be familiar with the outstanding records and types of hires.

 

2.The section 2 should not be completed until the hire emails the signed I-9 with their 3rd party, like a notary. Once the corporate representative receives the email they will go to the dashboard tile.

3.When the corporate representative opens the section 2 they will see the ‚ÄúIs the New Hire Remote?‚Äù populated as Yes. This mapped from Recruiting or was manually selected during the New Hire Data Review step

 

4.The corporate representative must upload the copy of the I-9 received from the hire, in the I-9 Document Attachments section of the screen.

 

5.Once this section 2 step is completed E-Verify will trigger like with the normal hire process.

Thanks,

Gopi

entry.title: SAP Commerce Cloud Media Import through API
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP Commerce Cloud, we've powerful API to do data synchronisation: Integration API Module. Basically, this OData/Integration is designed to work with data model mapping. For each table, we can define an Integration Object. And through this Integration Object, we can import or export data from database.  

However, Media Item is not physically stored in database. Media is stored in Blob Storage. And here lies the main issue for using Integration API module. To bypass this limitation, we could use Cloud Hotfolder. But this approach is not ideal for many reasons:

  • overhead : HTTPS data transfer (hotfolder blob storage) + file persistence + HTTPS data reading (hotfolder blob storage) + data processing (Commerce) + HTTPS data transfer (media blob storage)
  • asynchronous processing/manual validation: end result is known indirectly by checking BackOffice
  • settings: impex template and spring integration
  • deletion: data deletion will demand another impex/setting

A better approach is to use API and this article will explain how for doing Media Item import.

 

Native API v1

SmartEdit is using API v1 to push new media in content catalog. This API can be re-used even for product catalog. And it is defined under this following class : de.hybris.platform.cmswebservices.media.controller.CatalogVersionMediaController

For doing so, you need first to create a dedicated OAuth application client

INSERT_UPDATE OAuthClientDetails ; clientId[unique = true] ; resourceIds ; scope ; authorizedGrantTypes ; authorities ; clientSecret
; media_integration ; hybris ; basic ; client_credentials ; ROLE_ADMINGROUP ; secret

Then, you can get OAuth token simply by executing this following request

curl -v -k -X 'POST' https://localhost:9002/authorizationserver/oauth/token \
-d "grant_type=client_credentials" \
-d "client_id=media_integration" \
-d "client_secret=secret"

As result, you should get Bearer token

{"access_token":"....","token_type":"Bearer","expires_in":299}

And finally, to import your media, you can execute this following request

curl -v -k -X 'POST' 'https://localhost:9002/cmswebservices/v1/catalogs/electronicsProductCatalog/versions/Staged/media' \
-H 'Authorization: Bearer ...' \
-F "code=img.png" \
-F "description=img.png" \
-F "altText=img.png" \
-F "folder=images" \
-F "file=@img.png"

This API imports data in streaming. By consequence, you should not have memory leak issue when large file is imported. But file uploading size limitation is by default at 10MB.  

In other hand, this API capability is limited to media creation exclusively. Media cannot be updated or deleted through this API.

 

Custom OCC API (v2)

Knowing this API v1 limited capability, it makes sense to create a custom OCC API to get other HTTP method capacity as PUT and DELETE.

To create a new custom OCC API, you need to create a new extension by following this official documentation: Creating an OCC Extension

Pay attention, your extension name must end with occ suffix.

In your new extension, you should add an exception url path mapping for the filter baseSiteMatchingFilter. Indeed, base site information is not required for publishing new media

<alias alias="baseSiteMatchingFilter" name="customBaseSiteMatchingFilter" />
<bean id="customBaseSiteMatchingFilter" class="de.hybris.platform.commercewebservices.core.v2.filter.BaseSiteMatchingFilter">
 <property name="regexp" value="^/(?!(media)|(swagger)|(.*api-docs)|(csrf)|(webjars))([^/]+)" />
 <property name="baseSiteService" ref="baseSiteService" />
</bean>

Then, you need to create a new Controller. Please find in below pseudo code example.

@RequestMapping(value = "/media/{catalogId}/version/{versionId}")
@CacheControl(directive = CacheControlDirective.NO_CACHE)
@Tag(name = "Media Controller")
@Secured({ "ROLE_INTEGRATION" })
public class MediaController
@PostMapping(consumes = { MediaType.MULTIPART_FORM_DATA_VALUE })
@ResponseStatus(HttpStatus.CREATED)
[...]
public MediaData uploadMedia(...) {
 [...]
 return createOrUpdateMedia(media, folder, multiPart, false);
}

Processing logic should use as much as possible existing facade and service to minimise the customisation and to be agnostic regarding local implementation (filesystem) and cloud (blob storage)

private void removeMedia(String catalogId, String versionId, String code) {
 MediaModel exitingMedia = getMediaService().getMedia(getCatalogVersionService().getCatalogVersion(catalogId, versionId), code);
 getMediaService().removeDataFromMedia(exitingMedia);
 getModelService().remove(exitingMedia);
}

private MediaData createOrUpdateMedia(MediaData media, String folder, MultipartFile multiPart, boolean isUpdate) {
		try 
 		{
 		 if (isUpdate) {
		  removeMedia(media.getCatalogId(), media.getCatalogVersion(), media.getCode());
		 }
					
 final MediaData newMedia = getMediaFacade()
	.addMediaToFolder(media, getFile(multiPart, multiPart.getInputStream()), folder);
				IOUtils.closeQuietly(multiPart.getInputStream());
				return newMedia;
	}
	[...]
}

private MediaFileDto getFile(final MultipartFile file, final InputStream inputStream) {
 final MediaFileDto mediaFile = new MediaFileDto();
 mediaFile.setInputStream(inputStream);
 mediaFile.setName(file.getOriginalFilename());
 mediaFile.setSize(file.getSize());
 mediaFile.setMime(file.getContentType());
 return mediaFile;
}

By default, upload file size limitation is 10MB. This limitation is defined in commercewebservices/web.xml

<multipart-config>
 <location></location>
 <max-file-size>10485760</max-file-size>
 <max-request-size>-1</max-request-size>
 <file-size-threshold>0</file-size-threshold>
</multipart-config>

To test this new API, you have to create a dedicated OAuth client granted as ROLE_INTEGRATION

INSERT_UPDATE OAuthClientDetails ; clientId[unique = true] ; resourceIds ; scope ; authorizedGrantTypes ; authorities ; clientSecret
; media_integration ; hybris ; basic ; client_credentials ; ROLE_INTEGRATION ; secret

Then you can execute this following POST HTTP request to import the media into electronicsProductCatalog in Staged version.

curl -v -k -X 'POST' 'https://localhost:9002/occ/v2/media/electronicsProductCatalog/Staged' \
  -H 'Authorization: Bearer ...' \
  -F "code=img.png" \
  -F "description=img.png" \
  -F "altText=img.png" \
  -F "folder=images" \
  -F "file=@img.png"

 

Conclusion

As we can see, you can easily import media via the API, which will likely greatly simplify the end-to-end integration process.

If you need more support, please don't hesitate to contact SAP Expert Services.

entry.title: Re: Small program to test the SCSM_NW_WORKLOAD interface for reading ABAP statistics data
entry.content:
I made something else on a similar topic. I needed stats for 13 months back on one screen.
So i query monthly aggregates like this depending on what i need:

METHOD get_time_values.

    DATA: lt_hosts TYPE msxxlist_t,
          lv_host  TYPE swnchostname.

    REFRESH rt_tasks.

    CALL FUNCTION 'TH_SERVER_LIST' TABLES list = lt_hosts.

    lv_host = lt_hosts[ 1 ]-name. " there usually is just one instance

    CALL FUNCTION 'SWNC_COLLECTOR_GET_AGGREGATES'
      EXPORTING
        component     = lv_host
        periodtype    = 'M'
        periodstrt    = iv_date
        summary_only  = abap_true
      TABLES
        tasktype      = rt_tasks
      EXCEPTIONS
        no_data_found = 1
        OTHERS        = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD get_trans_values.

    DATA: lt_hosts TYPE msxxlist_t,
          lv_host  TYPE swnchostname.

    REFRESH rt_reps.

    CALL FUNCTION 'TH_SERVER_LIST' TABLES list = lt_hosts.

    lv_host = lt_hosts[ 1 ]-name. " there usually is just one instance

    CALL FUNCTION 'SWNC_COLLECTOR_GET_AGGREGATES'
      EXPORTING
        component     = lv_host
        periodtype    = 'M'
        periodstrt    = iv_date
*       summary_only  = abap_true
      TABLES
        times         = rt_reps
      EXCEPTIONS
        no_data_found = 1
        OTHERS        = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

entry.title: Auto fill "Created At" for date using Semantics annotations is not working in RAP
entry.content:
I have created a simple managed RAP application from a custom table which has a field called ERDAT. I want this field to be auto-filled whenever a user creates a new record.

I added the below semantic annotation in my root view entity (for ERDAT field)

 

define root view entity ZR_Sales_Header as select from YI_SALESORD_HDR_TEST
composition[1..*] of YI_SALES_ITEM as  _SalesOrdItem
association[0..1] to I_OverallSDProcessStatusText as _OverallProcStatusText
  on  $projection.GBSTK = _OverallProcStatusText.OverallSDProcessStatus 
  and _OverallProcStatusText.Language = $session.system_language
association[1..1] to ZI_CustomerNameText as _CustomerName
  on $projection.KUNNR = _CustomerName.Customer  
{
    key VBELN,
    @Semantics.systemDate.createdAt: true
    ERDAT,

The field name in DB table and CDS view entity is same (ERDAT) so no mapping is provided in RAP behaviour definition

In RAP Behv Definition, read only is applied for this field.

field ( readonly ) VBELN, ERDAT;

But when I run the app and try to create and save a new record, the field ERDAT comes are ready only but it does not get populated with the date and instead a blank value in this field gets saved in the DB table.

Also to add the data type of ERDAT in my database table is DATUM only.

Can anyone kindly point out what mistake I am doing here.

entry.title: Re: How to track stock by pack size (5/25/50kg) with one...
entry.content:
Dear @FaisalMaayeh,

Question 1.

  • Use one product/material and maintain Alternative Units of Measure (UoM) for example base KG: BG5 = 5 KG, BG25 = 25 KG, BG50 = 50 KG. SAP supports entering quantities in alternative UoMs while the system keeps stock in the base/stockkeeping UoM

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f86dc2eb1f8b48c880a7607213104b27/309ac253d0a4b54ce10000000a174cb4.html

  • If you scan/label by pack size, maintain GTIN/EAN per UoM, Public Cloud supports additional GTINs with alternative UoMs in the product context
  • Many implementations prefer Alternative UoM over creating multiple materials when the pack size is mainly a selling/ordering/picking unit and valuation is the same, for example SAP community below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/multiple-materials-vs-alternative-uom/qaq-p/6403513

If you don‚Äôt have suitable standard UoMs, in Public Edition you typically create them in CBC via the SSCUI for Units of Measurement

More details below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/how-to-create-new-unit-of-measure-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-2502/qaq-p/14024113

So the one-material best practice when cost is identical is alternative UoMs + GTINs per UoM if needed. This is the cleanest simplest model

Question 2.

  • Handling Unit Management is for representing packing-based logistics structures and tracking movements of packed units. Each HU has its own unique HU ID and contains packaging/material/weight/volume data

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/b4c3ead97179498b900e7a3e808c03af.html

  • Public Cloud provides warehouse apps to pack/manage HUs for example Pack Handling Units Advanced

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/87f9b54f9c4f4e75aff0061860a6589a/86ad0462af4c4fc592d2525d71bf974b.html

So best practice:

  • HU is usually best for what you physically handle as a unit typically pallets / cartons / containers
  • Making each bag an HU is technically possible but usually not realistic for high-volume, low-value items because you explode HU count exactly what you noticed
  • Keep bags as quantities in BG5/BG25/BG50 via Alternative UoM
  • Use Packaging Specifications to drive how quantities are packed (1 pallet = 40 √ó BG25 and then create one HU per pallet not per bag

Summary:

  • HU management is more for pallets/cartons

  • Bags should usually be handled as quantities (UoM), not as individual HUs, unless you truly need bag-level traceability

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Exploring End-to-End Business Processes in SAP Business Suite
entry.content:
Modern business processes such as procurement, production, sales, service, finance, controlling, and human resources are highly interconnected and characterized by numerous interfaces, dependencies, and dynamic integration points. Consistent master data usage and close cross-functional collaboration are essential to meet time, cost, and quality objectives.

SAP provides an integrated solution portfolio that supports these end-to-end business processes based on modern technologies and evolving business requirements. Due to the breadth and continuous evolution of the SAP portfolio, gaining an initial overview can be challenging. The objective is therefore to offer a structured understanding of SAP process terminology, integration concepts, and corresponding solutions.

Mapping SAP Solutions

 

Finance as a core function of end-to-end business processes

Finance ensures the proper recording, processing and evaluation of all financial transactions of a company. It reflects the financial reality of operations and ensures compliance with legal, regulatory and country-specific accounting standards.

Duties and responsibilities

Its core tasks include the continuous posting of business transactions, the analysis of financial data and its structured reporting. Finance thus provides the basis for transparency, control and external reporting.

Central interfaces

Finance is closely interlinked with other areas of the company:

  • Customers / Debtors: Receivables management and complaint support
  • Sales: Early detection of credit risks and clarification of payment or delivery problems
  • Procurement: Review of incoming invoices and management of accounts payable

These interfaces make finance an integrative cross-sectional function.

Typical results

  • Periodic financial statements (balance sheet, profit and loss account, cash flow statement)
  • Maintain and manage accounts receivable, vendor, and asset data
  • Financial and liquidity reporting for management and controlling

Critical success factors

  • High data quality and timely availability of financial information
  • Transparent assessment of creditworthiness and payment behavior
  • Compliance with compliance and risk management requirements
  • Consistent master data and end-to-end system integration

Conclusion

Finance is a central integration point of end-to-end business processes. Incorrect or delayed data transfers have a direct impact on transparency, controllability and compliance.

 

Controlling as a management function of the company

Controlling supports management by planning, calculating, analysing and communicating financial information. It creates transparency about the economic situation of the company and serves as internal control, control and decision-making support.

Duties and responsibilities

The core tasks of controlling include internal planning, budgeting, control and reporting on the financial health of the company. The focus is on the analysis of costs, revenues and profitability as well as on the derivation of key performance indicators relevant to management.

Central interfaces

Controlling works closely with operational and market-related departments:

  • Production: Cost and revenue control via cost accounting, budgeting of organizational expenses, and planning and estimating production costs
  • Marketing and Sales: Providing information on sales variances to adjust sales campaigns or correct price ranges

Typical results

  • Analysis results and management reports to assess financial soundness
  • Cost, result and variance analyses
  • Decision-making bases for improving cost accounting and financial planning

Critical success factors

  • Effective, realistic planning and budgeting
  • Accurate, consistent, and timely data
  • Appropriate control and key performance indicator systems

Conclusion

Controlling is the central control body between operational business and management. The quality and timeliness of data as well as clearly defined control systems are crucial for effective corporate management and well-founded decisions.

 

Human Resources as a Structuring Business Process (R2R-Recruit To Retire)

Human Resources ensures that the company  has qualified, efficient and motivated employees. It is responsible for all HR-related business processes along the entire employee lifecycle and thus makes a significant contribution to operational stability and strategic development.

Duties and responsibilities

Core responsibilities include recruiting employees with the right qualifications, onboarding new employees in a structured manner, and managing performance, training, and development opportunities. In addition, HR is responsible for payroll, pension and additional benefits as well as all other cost-relevant personnel topics. Another focus is on improving employee and professional experience.

Central interfaces

Human Resources is a cross-departmental cross-sectional function:

  • All departments: Implement performance management systems, employee and benefits programs, and secure budgets for personnel and compensation changes
  • Internal and external accounting: reconciliation of payroll, HR-related costs, accruals and budget planning

Typical results

  • Employee surveys and evaluations
  • Leadership, training, and development programs
  • Proper payroll
  • Culture, Health, and Employee Retention Programs

Critical success factors

  • Clear strategic alignment of workforce and capacity planning
  • Successfully attracting and retaining talent
  • Effective, transparent performance management
  • Reliable, integrated workforce data and processes

Conclusion in the context of business process analysis

Human resources is a central end-to-end business process . Media disruptions, a lack of integration with finance or unclear responsibilities have a direct impact on costs, employee satisfaction and performance. An end-to-end HR process is therefore an essential prerequisite for stable and scalable business processes.

See the deep dive for more Informations:

Recruit to Retire ‚Äì E2E Process Deep Dive

 

Procurement as an operational and strategic business process (S2P source-to-pay)

Procurement ensures that the company  is supplied with goods and services in a timely manner, cost-efficiently and in suitable quality. It supports both operational operations and strategic value creation.

Duties and responsibilities

The core tasks of procurement include overseeing all goods and service requirements, selecting reliable suppliers, and concluding and managing supplier contracts. In addition, procurement procures items to support internal business operations and takes purchasing positions to manufacture products.

Central interfaces

Procurement is closely interlinked with commercial and operational areas:

  • Controlling: Coordination for the planning and budgeting of order items
  • Financial accounting: Close collaboration, as accounts payable is part of financial accounting
  • Departments: Notification of requirements and use of purchasing catalogs

Typical results

  • Available materials in stock
  • Valid supplier contracts
  • Standardized purchasing catalogs for employees

Critical success factors

  • Strategic Sourcing and Effective Stakeholder Management
  • Reliable, efficient and sustainable suppliers
  • Efficient, transparent purchasing processes

Conclusion

Procurement is a central end-to-end business process that directly influences costs, delivery capability and productivity. Close integration with controlling and financial accounting as well as efficient, digitally supported processes are crucial for a stable supply and sustainable value creation.

See the deep dive for more Informations:

DiveSource to Pay E2E Process Deep Dive

 

Sales as a revenue-driving end-to-end business process (L2C - Lead to Cash)

Sales is responsible for the sale of goods and services and is largely responsible for revenue generation and profitability. It covers the entire process from new customer acquisition to quotation preparation and order fulfillment.

Duties and responsibilities

The core tasks of sales include the acquisition of new customers, the maintenance of existing customer relationships and the implementation of presales activities. Sales creates quotes, takes customer orders, fulfills them in collaboration with the supply chain, and plans future sales.

Central interfaces

Sales is closely involved in cross-departmental processes:

  • Marketing: Using marketing leads to create targeted offers and contracts
  • Internal and external accounting: Reporting and reconciliation of revenues from customer orders
  • Service: Support of service sales, e.g. through consulting or support services

Typical results

  • Quotes and confirmed customer orders
  • Long-term and sustainable customer relationships
  • Revenue and sales plans

Critical success factors

  • Effective sales estimates and realistic sales planning
  • Seamless integration into the supply chain
  • High customer satisfaction
  • Sustainable revenue generation and increased profitability

Conclusion

Sales is a central end-to-end business process whose performance depends directly on integration with marketing, service, logistics and finance. Media disruptions or a lack of coordination have a direct impact on customer satisfaction, sales and margins.

See the deep dive for more Informations:

Lead to Cash ‚Äì E2E Process Deep Dive

 

Production as a value-adding core process (D2O Design To Operate)

Production is responsible for the production of finished products using materials, machines and labour. The aim is on-time and high-quality production at the lowest possible cost ‚Äì in the example of the Bike Company, the production of bicycles.

Duties and responsibilities

The core tasks of production include the conversion of materials into finished products and compliance with defined manufacturing processes. Standardised processes reduce production costs, ensure quality and meet delivery deadlines.

Central interfaces

Production is closely linked to commercial and upstream functions:

  • Controlling / internal accounting: Estimation, planning and analysis of production costs
  • Financial accounting: Reporting of production and cost data as well as optimization of product costs
  • Procurement: Ensuring material availability through timely purchase of the required components

Typical results

  • Finished bikes that meet quality standards
  • Timely delivery of products
  • Production and cost data for other divisions

Critical success factors

  • Availability of materials, machines and personnel
  • Efficient, stable production processes
  • Minor variances between actual and planned costs

Conclusion

Production is the  company's central value-added process. Close integration with procurement, finance and controlling is crucial to controlling costs, ensuring quality and reliably guaranteeing delivery capability.

See the deep dive for more Informations:

Design to Operate E2E Process Deep Dive

 

Service as a customer-loyal end-to-end business process

The service ensures the maintenance, support and servicing of sold products . It makes a significant contribution to customer satisfaction, customer loyalty and long-term value creation.

Duties and responsibilities

The core tasks of the service include the execution of maintenance and services, the provision of round-the-clock support and the planning and handling of service visits. A central component is ensuring the availability of spare parts and qualified service staff.

Central interfaces

The service is closely interlinked with other company divisions:

  • Sales: Sharing service histories, handling customer and support requests, and supporting service sales
  • Procurement: Coordination to ensure that required spare parts are available and delivered within 24 hours

Typical results

  • Round-the-clock support and service delivery
  • Service visits carried out with spare parts and qualified service employees
  • Fully documented service histories

Critical success factors

  • Short response times and spare parts availability within 24 hours
  • Effective planning of service costs and deadlines
  • Use of digital technologies, e.g. Internet of Things (IoT) for premium bicycles

Conclusion

Service is a crucial end-to-end post-sale business process . Close integration with sales and procurement as well as data-based, digitally supported service processes are central to high customer satisfaction and sustainable customer relationships.

 

Process Integration

The following graphic illustrates process steps within the end-to-end processes Lead to Cash, Source to Pay, Design to Operate, Recruit to Retire and their main integration points.

Process Integration

 

End-to-End Business Processes and Integration Challenges

SAP end-to-end (E2E) business processes cover the entire flow of a business function across departments, eliminating fragmentation. Sales, supply chain, procurement, finance, and HR are integrated into a single, intelligent workflow.

Key Benefits of SAP

  • Integration: Unified platform connecting all core business functions

  • Efficiency: Automation reduces manual effort and errors

  • Data Consistency: Centralized data as a single source of truth

  • Compliance: Built-in support for regulatory requirements

  • Scalability: Flexible solutions that grow with the business

  • Real-Time Insights: Up-to-date analytics for better decisions

  • Customer Satisfaction: Faster, more reliable processes improve service quality

entry.title: Quickly Inspect your Java Application with JStall
entry.content:
I hope I'm not the only one who sometimes wonders: "What is my Java application doing right now?" When you don't see any output. Yes, you could perform a simple thread dump via jstack, but it is hard to understand which threads are actually consuming CPU and making any sort of progress. This is where my tiny tool called JStall comes in:

JStall is a small command-line tool for one-shot inspection of running JVMs using thread dumps and short, on-demand profiling. The tool essentially takes multiple thread dumps of your application and uses the per-thread cpu-time information to find the most CPU-time-consuming Java threads.

First, download the JStall executable from the GitHub releases page. Let us then start by finding the currently running JVMs:

> ./jstall
Usage: jstall <command> <pid|files> [options]

Available commands:
  status     - Show overall status (deadlocks + most active threads)
  list       - List and filter JVMs
  deadlock   - Check for deadlocks
  most-work  - Show threads doing the most work
  flame      - Generate flame graph
  threads    - List all threads

Available JVMs:
   1223 <unknown>
   8136 ./renaissance-gpl-0.16.0.jar
   6138 org.jetbrains.idea.maven.server.RemoteMavenServer36
   5597 DeadlockDemo
  49294 com.intellij.idea.Main

This provides us with a list of options for the main status command, as well as a list of JVM processes and their corresponding main classes.

Deadlock

Process 5597 is an instance of the DeadlockDemo program that we saw running above. Let's obtain the status (a combination of deadlock and most-work analysis):

> ./jstall 5597
=== deadlock ===
Deadlock detected:

Found one Java-level deadlock:
=============================
"DeadlockThread-1":
  waiting to lock monitor 0x00006000029215f0 (object 0x000000052f817880, a java.lang.Object),
  which is held by "DeadlockThread-2"

"DeadlockThread-2":
  waiting to lock monitor 0x00006000029280d0 (object 0x000000052f817878, a java.lang.Object),
  which is held by "DeadlockThread-1"

Java stack information for the threads listed above:
===================================================
"DeadlockThread-1":
        at DeadlockDemo.lambda$main$0(scratch_2.java:15)
        - waiting to lock <0x000000052f817880> (a java.lang.Object)
        - locked <0x000000052f817878> (a java.lang.Object)
        at DeadlockDemo$$Lambda/0x000007fc01040400.run(Unknown Source)
        at java.lang.Thread.runWith(java.base@25/Thread.java:1487)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(java.base@25/Thread.java:1474)
"DeadlockThread-2":
        at DeadlockDemo.lambda$main$1(scratch_2.java:26)
        - waiting to lock <0x000000052f817878> (a java.lang.Object)
        - locked <0x000000052f817880> (a java.lang.Object)
        at DeadlockDemo$$Lambda/0x000007fc01040800.run(Unknown Source)
        at java.lang.Thread.runWith(java.base@25/Thread.java:1487)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(java.base@25/Thread.java:1474)

Found one Java-level deadlock:
=============================
"DeadlockThread-3":
  waiting to lock monitor 0x0000600002938000 (object 0x000000052f817890, a java.lang.Object),
  which is held by "DeadlockThread-4"

"DeadlockThread-4":
  waiting to lock monitor 0x0000600002934000 (object 0x000000052f817888, a java.lang.Object),
  which is held by "DeadlockThread-3"

Java stack information for the threads listed above:
===================================================
"DeadlockThread-3":
        at DeadlockDemo.lambda$main$2(scratch_2.java:38)
        - waiting to lock <0x000000052f817890> (a java.lang.Object)
        - locked <0x000000052f817888> (a java.lang.Object)
        at DeadlockDemo$$Lambda/0x000007fc01040c00.run(Unknown Source)
        at java.lang.Thread.runWith(java.base@25/Thread.java:1487)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(java.base@25/Thread.java:1474)
"DeadlockThread-4":
        at DeadlockDemo.lambda$main$3(scratch_2.java:49)
        - waiting to lock <0x000000052f817888> (a java.lang.Object)
        - locked <0x000000052f817890> (a java.lang.Object)
        at DeadlockDemo$$Lambda/0x000007fc01041000.run(Unknown Source)
        at java.lang.Thread.runWith(java.base@25/Thread.java:1487)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(java.base@25/Thread.java:1474)

Found 2 deadlocks.

=== most-work ===
Top threads by activity (2 dumps):
Combined CPU time: 0.00s, Elapsed time: 5.10s (0.0% overall utilization)

1. Monitor Deflation Thread
   CPU time: 0.00s (64.8% of total)
   Core utilization: 0.0%
   States: RUNNABLE: 100.0%
2. Service Thread
   CPU time: 0.00s (14.8% of total)
   Core utilization: 0.0%
   States: RUNNABLE: 100.0%
3. Attach Listener
   CPU time: 0.00s (13.6% of total)
   Core utilization: 0.0%
   States: RUNNABLE: 100.0%

For this, JStack obtained two thread dumps and analyzed them. JStack found two thread dumps and identified that the top CPU-time-consuming threads are JVM-related.

Listing All Threads

Using the threads command, we can take a look at all threads:

> ./jstall threads 5597
Threads (2 dumps):
Combined CPU time: 0.00s, Elapsed time: 5.10s (0.0% overall utilization)

THREAD                    CPU TIME  CPU %  STATES         TOP STACK FRAME                                   
------------------------  --------  -----  -------------  --------------------------------------------------
Monitor Deflation Thread     0.00s  65.2%  RUNNABLE                                                         
Service Thread               0.00s  18.5%  RUNNABLE                                                         
Attach Listener              0.00s   7.6%  RUNNABLE                                                         
C1 CompilerThread0           0.00s   4.3%  RUNNABLE                                                         
C2 CompilerThread0           0.00s   4.3%  RUNNABLE                                                         
Common-Cleaner               0.00s   0.0%  TIMED_WAITING  java.lang.Object.wait0                            
DeadlockThread-1             0.00s   0.0%  BLOCKED        DeadlockDemo.lambda$main$0                        
DeadlockThread-2             0.00s   0.0%  BLOCKED        DeadlockDemo.lambda$main$1                        
DeadlockThread-3             0.00s   0.0%  BLOCKED        DeadlockDemo.lambda$main$2                        
DeadlockThread-4             0.00s   0.0%  BLOCKED        DeadlockDemo.lambda$main$3                        
Finalizer                    0.00s   0.0%  WAITING        java.lang.Object.wait0                            
Notification Thread          0.00s   0.0%  RUNNABLE                                                         
Reference Handler            0.00s   0.0%  RUNNABLE       java.lang.ref.Reference.waitForReferencePending...
Signal Dispatcher            0.00s   0.0%  RUNNABLE                                                         
main                         0.00s   0.0%  WAITING        java.lang.Object.wait0

It's also possible to use jstack threads Dead now, selecting JVMs by giving parts of their label.

The threads command provides a concise overview of the app's progress

Status of a Renaissance Instance

Let's look at process 8136, which is an instance of the Renaissance benchmark suite.

> ./jstall 8136
=== most-work ===
Top threads by activity (2 dumps):
Combined CPU time: 13.34s, Elapsed time: 5.11s (261.4% overall utilization)

1. Executor task launch worker for task 0.0 in stage 53.0 (TID 75)
   CPU time: 4.14s (31.1% of total)
   Core utilization: 81.2%
   States: RUNNABLE: 100.0%
   Common stack prefix:
     org.apache.spark.util.collection.SizeTrackingAppendOnlyMap.changeValue(SizeTrackingAppendOnlyMap.scala:32)
     org.apache.spark.util.collection.ExternalSorter.insertAll(ExternalSorter.scala:200)
     org.apache.spark.shuffle.sort.SortShuffleWriter.write(SortShuffleWriter.scala:63)
     org.apache.spark.shuffle.ShuffleWriteProcessor.write(ShuffleWriteProcessor.scala:59)
     org.apache.spark.scheduler.ShuffleMapTask.runTask(ShuffleMapTask.scala:104)
     org.apache.spark.scheduler.ShuffleMapTask.runTask(ShuffleMapTask.scala:54)
     org.apache.spark.TaskContext.runTaskWithListeners(TaskContext.scala:166)
     org.apache.spark.scheduler.Task.run(Task.scala:141)
     org.apache.spark.executor.Executor$TaskRunner.$anonfun$run$4(Executor.scala:620)
     org.apache.spark.executor.Executor$TaskRunner$$Lambda/0x0000030001959c00.apply
   ... (8 more lines)

2. Executor task launch worker for task 1.0 in stage 53.0 (TID 76)
   CPU time: 4.12s (30.9% of total)
   Core utilization: 80.8%
   States: RUNNABLE: 100.0%
   Common stack prefix:
     org.apache.spark.util.collection.SizeTrackingAppendOnlyMap.changeValue(SizeTrackingAppendOnlyMap.scala:32)
     org.apache.spark.util.collection.ExternalSorter.insertAll(ExternalSorter.scala:200)
     org.apache.spark.shuffle.sort.SortShuffleWriter.write(SortShuffleWriter.scala:63)
     org.apache.spark.shuffle.ShuffleWriteProcessor.write(ShuffleWriteProcessor.scala:59)
     org.apache.spark.scheduler.ShuffleMapTask.runTask(ShuffleMapTask.scala:104)
     org.apache.spark.scheduler.ShuffleMapTask.runTask(ShuffleMapTask.scala:54)
     org.apache.spark.TaskContext.runTaskWithListeners(TaskContext.scala:166)
     org.apache.spark.scheduler.Task.run(Task.scala:141)
     org.apache.spark.executor.Executor$TaskRunner.$anonfun$run$4(Executor.scala:620)
     org.apache.spark.executor.Executor$TaskRunner$$Lambda/0x0000030001959c00.apply
   ... (8 more lines)

3. Executor task launch worker for task 2.0 in stage 53.0 (TID 77)
   CPU time: 4.06s (30.4% of total)
   Core utilization: 79.5%
   States: RUNNABLE: 100.0%
   Common stack prefix:
     org.apache.spark.util.collection.SizeTrackingAppendOnlyMap.changeValue(SizeTrackingAppendOnlyMap.scala:32)
     org.apache.spark.util.collection.ExternalSorter.insertAll(ExternalSorter.scala:200)
     org.apache.spark.shuffle.sort.SortShuffleWriter.write(SortShuffleWriter.scala:63)
     org.apache.spark.shuffle.ShuffleWriteProcessor.write(ShuffleWriteProcessor.scala:59)
     org.apache.spark.scheduler.ShuffleMapTask.runTask(ShuffleMapTask.scala:104)
     org.apache.spark.scheduler.ShuffleMapTask.runTask(ShuffleMapTask.scala:54)
     org.apache.spark.TaskContext.runTaskWithListeners(TaskContext.scala:166)
     org.apache.spark.scheduler.Task.run(Task.scala:141)
     org.apache.spark.executor.Executor$TaskRunner.$anonfun$run$4(Executor.scala:620)
     org.apache.spark.executor.Executor$TaskRunner$$Lambda/0x0000030001959c00.apply
   ... (8 more lines)

Here, you see the top three (configurable) CPU-time-consuming threads over the last 10 seconds, along with the stack trace parts common to both thread dumps.

Using the threads command, you can again see all threads:

> ./jstall threads 8136
Threads (2 dumps):
Combined CPU time: 13.12s, Elapsed time: 5.11s (256.8% overall utilization)

THREAD                                              CPU TIME  CPU %  STATES                       TOP STACK FRAME                                   
--------------------------------------------------  --------  -----  ---------------------------  --------------------------------------------------
Executor task launch worker for task 1.0 in sta...     4.16s  31.7%  RUNNABLE: 50%, BLOCKED: 50%  java.lang.ClassValue$ClassValueMap.readAccess     
Executor task launch worker for task 2.0 in sta...     4.16s  31.7%  RUNNABLE                     scala.runtime.ClassValueCompat.get                
Executor task launch worker for task 0.0 in sta...     4.05s  30.9%  RUNNABLE                     org.apache.spark.util.collection.SizeTrackingAp...
main                                                   0.20s   1.5%  WAITING                      jdk.internal.misc.Unsafe.park                     
C2 CompilerThread0                                     0.16s   1.2%  RUNNABLE                                                                       
task-result-getter-1                                   0.07s   0.6%  WAITING                      jdk.internal.misc.Unsafe.park                     
task-result-getter-0                                   0.07s   0.5%  WAITING                      jdk.internal.misc.Unsafe.park                     
...

But thread dumps aren't the only way to peek at a running Java application; you can also take a short profile and generate a flamegraph:

Generating Flamegraphs

For this purpose, I integrated async-profiler using my ap-loader library:

> ./jstall flame 8136  
Starting flamegraph generation for PID 8136...
Event: cpu
Duration: 10s
Interval: 10ms
Output: flame.html

Executing: asprof -d 10 -e cpu -i 10000000 -f flame.html 8136

Profiling for 10 seconds
Done

‚úì Flamegraph successfully generated!
Output file: .../flame.html
File size: 349576 bytes

Which results in this rather unwieldy flamegraph, courtesy of the Apache Spark benchmark:

 

Adding Analyses

Do you have an idea for another thread dump analysis? Just implement the Analysis interface, create a CLI command class, and submit a pull request on GitHub. The Analysis interface is pretty simple:

public interface Analyzer {

    /**
     * Returns the name of this analyzer.
     */
    String name();

    /**
     * Returns the set of options this analyzer supports.
     *
     * Common options: "dumps", "interval", "keep", "top"
     */
    Set<String> supportedOptions();

    /**
     * Returns the dump requirement for this analyzer.
     */
    DumpRequirement dumpRequirement();

    default AnalyzerResult analyze(List<ThreadDumpWithRaw> dumpsWithRaw, 
      Map<String, Object> options) {
        List<ThreadDump> dumps = dumpsWithRaw.stream().map(ThreadDumpWithRaw::parsed).toList();
        return analyzeThreadDumps(dumps, options);
    }

    default AnalyzerResult analyzeThreadDumps(List<ThreadDump> dumps, 
     Map<String, Object> options) {
        throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
            "Analyzer must implement either analyze(List<ThreadDumpWithRaw>, Map) " + 
            "or analyzeThreadDumps(List<ThreadDump>, Map)");
    }
}

Additionally, there are helper classes that make writing new analyses even easier. So feel free to submit your own. Ideas for new analyses could be:

  • A lock view that emits a lock graph
  • A thread-state analysis
  • A thread blockage analysis that takes the top stack frames and determines whether the threads are waiting for IO, user input, or something else

The threaddump analyses use the jthreaddump parsing library, which you can also use for your own projects.

Conclusion

I sometimes get the time to write tools that solve minor annoyances, in this case, finding the status of a Java app. I hope you find JStall as helpful as I do, and make this open-source project part of your daily toolbox. Feel free to contribute via GitHub issues or pull requests.

This article is part of my work in the SapMachine team at SAP, making profiling and debugging easier for everyone.

P.S.: Never stop exploring...

P.P.S.: You can, of course, use the JStack tool via jbang too: jbang jstall@parttimenerd/jstall

 

P.P.P.S: Abschalten

entry.title: Re: How to track stock by pack size (5/25/50kg) with one...
entry.content:
That is a very comprehensive answer indeed. Kudos well received.

However, I would not agree with the summary, i.e.

  • HU management is more for pallets/cartons
  • Bags should usually be handled as quantities (UoM), not as individual HUs, unless you truly need bag-level traceability

Bags can be modeled as handling units as well, just the same way as cartons. It all depends on business needs. Per definition a handling unit is a:

A physical item consisting of packaging materials and the material they contain. A handling unit(HU) has a single, scannable identification number that can be used to call up the data.

A product can be packed in a carton (a handling unit) and cartons can be packed on a pallet (a handling unit). The same way, a product (cement) can be packed in a bag (a handling unit) and bags can be packed on a pallet (a handling unit).

Of course such a detailed tracking, down to bags or cartons, will generate operational overhead to label, scan, inventory those bags or cartons. Thus, the question is if it is worth the effort.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Re: System limitation of 999 line items per Physical inve...
entry.content:
You have a few options:

Split by storage location / bin / material group:
Use selection criteria when creating the inventory documents so that each run produces fewer than 999 lines. For example, run AS separately for each storage location or material type.

Batch job with variants:
Schedule multiple runs of the inventory creation program (RLMOB010 or RM07II00 depending on your setup) with different variants, each covering a subset of materials.

Custom enhancement:
If you want true auto‚Äësplitting, you‚Äôd need an enhancement (user exit or BAdI) in the inventory creation program to check line count and start a new document once 999 is reached.

EWM approach:
In Decentralized EWM, you can use storage bin‚Äìbased inventory. The system creates one document per bin, which naturally keeps line counts below the limit.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Maintain tax rate with reference to HSN for...
entry.content:
Why it works with Standard Procedure A18001 but not with your custom one could be because of condition type TTX1 is delivered by SAP and tied to the standard access sequence and pricing procedure. When you copy or create a custom pricing procedure, you must ensure the condition type TTX1 is included in the procedure. The access sequence ZTX1 is correctly assigned to TTX1. The pricing procedure determination (Purchasing schema determination) points to your custom procedure. If the PO is using your custom procedure but the condition type is missing or not active, the system won‚Äôt determine the tax code even though the condition record exists.

Check the below areas:

Pricing Procedure Assignment
Go to SSCUI 101095 (Define Calculation Schema for Purchasing). Verify that your custom schema includes condition type TTX1 with access sequence ZTX1.

Schema Determination
SSCUI 101096 (Determine Calculation Schema for Standard Purchase Orders). Ensure your purchasing organization/vendor combination points to your custom schema.

Field Mapping Consistency
The fields in your condition table (533) must match the values available in the PO. Example: Region (REGIO) and PlantRegion (WKREG) must be filled in the PO master data. If blank, the condition won‚Äôt find a match.

Condition Record Validity
Double‚Äëcheck the condition record in Set Tax Rates ‚Äì Purchasing. Ensure validity dates cover the PO date. Ensure no overlapping records exist that confuse determination.

Tax Code Field Behavior
In Public Cloud, the tax code field in PO is determined by condition type TTX1. If your custom schema doesn‚Äôt trigger TTX1, the field stays blank.

entry.title: Re: ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development
entry.content:
Hi Tobias @ttrapp ,

you can provide the files with released APIs like objectReleaseInfo_PCELatest.json only in the "Released API Data Source" check parameter. In this case the check will use the released APIs from the file instead of released APIs in your system. You can not change the classic APIs file, there is only one file objectClassifications_SAP.json  with the latest classic APIs, which gets updated if new classic APIs become available (currently the latest update is 2 weeks old).

Kind regards,
Olga.

entry.title: Re: How to maintain multiple address in public cloud? In...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you cannot use MEAN (which exists only in on‚Äëpremise) to maintain multiple delivery addresses. Instead, you manage delivery addresses in the Purchase Order app via the Delivery Address tab. For multiple addresses, you either:

  • Maintain address numbers in the Business Partner master data and select them in the PO, or
  • Use a BAdI to extend delivery address handling if you need more than one per storage location.

entry.title: Re: System limitation of 999 line items per Physical inve...
entry.content: Split by storage location / bin / material group: Use selection criteria when creating the inventory documents so that each run produces fewer than 999 lines. For example, run AS separately for each storage location or material type.

entry.title: Enhancing SAP HANA Database Development with Generative AI Support for HDI Artifacts
entry.content:
Introduction
 
Authoring HDI (HANA Deployment Infrastructure) artifacts‚Äîsuch as tables, views, roles, and synonyms‚Äîoften starts with a specification and ends with carefully structured definitions. This update streamlines the journey by adding a Joule icon directly in the editor. One click opens Joule with the /hdi-gen slash command preselected, so you can describe what you need in natural language and receive a ready-to-use HDI artifact definition.
 
What‚Äôs new
 
  • Joule icon in the editor: Visible when a supported HDI artifact file is active
  • One-click, context-aware start: Opens Joule with /hdi-gen preselected for HDI generation
  • Natural language to HDI: Describe the artifact you want and receive a valid HDI definition
  • Clear, safe application: Options to append to your file or replace its content
How it works

  • Open a supported HDI artifact file (for example, a table, view, role, or synonym).
  •  Click the Joule icon in the editor title bar.
  • Joule opens with /hdi-gen preselected.
  • Describe what you want (for example: ‚ÄúCreate a ROW table CUSTOMERS with ID INTEGER primary key and NAME NVARCHAR(100)‚Äù).
  • Joule returns a definition aligned with HDI best practices and your current file context.
  • Apply the result:
    • Append adds content to the end of your file
    • Replace substitutes the entire file content
The experience covers a broad range of HDI artifacts, including (but not limited to) tables, views, roles, synonyms, sequences, structured privileges, triggers, table data (hdbtabledata/csv), logical schemas, virtual tables, and related configuration files. The icon appears only when a supported file type is active and is opened in Code Editor.
 
Built-in guardrails
  • Native HDI syntax: No CREATE/DROP statements; output follows HDI file conventions
  • Identifier style: Uppercase identifiers by default, unless you specify otherwise
  • Table data: For hdbtabledata/csv, sample rows are generated without header lines
Why this matters
 
  1. Reduce time from requirement to definition using natural language
  2. Keep control: You decide when and how the result is applied
  3. Maintain clarity: Generated content is visibly sectioned for quick review and versioning
  4. Improve consistency: Definitions follow HDI best practices
Getting started
  • Open a supported HDI artifact file in your editor
  • Click the in-editor Joule icon(appears on top-right corner of the editor)
  • Describe your requirement and apply the result
This enhancement brings conversational HDI generation directly into your editor. With the Joule icon and /hdi-gen preselected, you can move from intent to artifact faster‚Äîwithout sacrificing clarity, safety, or control.
 
Supported artifacts
 
csv, hdbapplicationtime, hdbcollection, hdbconstraint, hdbdropcreatetable, hdbeshconfig, hdbfunction, hdbgraphworkspace, hdbgrants, hdbindex, hdblibrary, hdblogicalschema, hdblogicalschemaconfig, hdbmigrationtable, hdbprocedure, hdbprojectionview, hdbprojectionviewconfig, hdbpublicsynonym, hdbresultcache, hdbrole, hdbroleconfig, hdbsequence, hdbstatistics, hdbstructuredprivilege, hdbsynonym, hdbsynonymconfig, hdbsystemversioning, hdbtable, hdbtabledata, hdbtabletype, hdbtrigger, hdbview, hdbvirtualprocedure, hdbvirtualtable, hdbvirtualtableconfig, hdinamespace, properties

entry.title: Re: SAP DM ST2300 - Use of ESEF transformation registry v...
entry.content:
Hi Marc,

Thank you for your reply.

Could you please confirm whether version ST2300 can be used for ESEF reporting in the following configuration in 2025?
-Taxonomy 2024 / -Transformation Rules Register Version 4 (perhaps there is a workaround that allows version 5 to be used) / - Rule set: esef-2025

Can I find information in the SAP DM documentation about whether version ST2300 meets the requirements of the ESEF manual for October 2025?

Currently, when using version ST2300 in the 2025 annual report, we get the following error: [ESEF.2.2.3.incorrectTransformationRuleApplied] ESMA recommends applying the Transformation Rules Registry 5, as published by XBRL International or any more recent versions of the Transformation Rules Registry provided with a 'Recommendation' status, for these..

The release of version ST2301 is too far away and is not feasible given the short time remaining until the final closure of the ESEF reporting process in our case.

I would be grateful for any suggestions regarding ESEF reporting on the ST2300 version.

Regards, Iwona

entry.title: How to Access your SAP Business Data Cloud Free Trial
entry.content:
You probably have heard about Business Data Cloud, our Software as a Service Analytics platform. It allows you to combine our different cloud-based analytics solutions, such as SAP Datasphere, SAP BW or BW/4HANA as private cloud edition, SAP Analytics Cloud, and partner tools for machine learning, such as SAP Databricks. Moreover, we provide content for standard topics such as finance, or HR content in the form of data products and intelligent applications. These are SAP-defined datasets and interactive dashboards. Do you like to learn how you can find and consume such an intelligent application, how you can integrate SAP Databricks capabilities, how you can enrich models in SAP datasphere, and how you can customize applications in SAP Analytics cloud?  

Then, test our Business Data Cloud free trial and see how the components in Business Data Cloud looks like.

In this blog, follow a step by step procedure to get your free trial running.

1. Start your trial

Go to the web page http://sap.com/products/data-cloud/trial.html

 

Choose ‚ÄúTry now‚Äù to start your free trial.

If you are already working actively with an sap.com account, you will see this page:

which provides you with a generated user and password. Note down these credentials. If you are already logged on with sap.com, you will not need credentials and the page tells you that you can use your sap.com account to login.

2. Check out additional resources

It might take a few minutes to generate your user profile. I recommend that you check the website and FAQ in parallel (follow the links). On our website, you can already take a product tour.

3. Check your email inbox

In parallel, you received an e-mail message with a link to the corresponding course.

Choose ‚ÄúStart your basic trial‚Äù from this message or ‚ÄúClick here to start your basic trial‚Äù from the initial web page. Our online course opens.

4. Start the course with steps for your free trial.

Choose "start learning" to start the course. Follow Unit 1 for preparation and basic information.

You will find the link to the free trial inside the lesson ‚ÄúLog on to SAP Business Data Cloud‚Äù.

5. Login to the Free Trial

Follow the "click here" link. 

If you are already connected to sap.com, you will directly be redirected to the Business Data Cloud Cockpit page. Otherwise, you need to enter the credentials given to you after step 1.

6. Perform the demo steps in your free trial system.

Our course provides a typical SAP Business Data Cloud use case: enhancing existing standard data products with machine learning capabilities. The lesson details guide you through the steps that can be performed in your free trial, such as searching intelligent applications and data packages. Some steps that take rather long or are one-time administration tasks are provided as interective click-through demo scripts, but many other activities can be done in the system by you manually.

Take your time to proceed through the steps at your own speed. If the trial period ends, you can always ask for a new trial.

If the trial period ends, you can always ask for a new trial.

I hope you are enjoying this hands-on experience. I am looking forward to comments and questions. Besides, you can book some SAP Business Data Cloud related live sessions and ask your questions there. See you soon.

Alexander Scivos

entry.title: Re: Dual line chart using macros and odata v4
entry.content:
Hi,

I would still appreciate if some expert could help me with this issue.

After some debugging, I've found that only one dimension is being included as dynamic property.

In the previous annotations, if I comment all parts related to the property "resolvedSum", the method

add_dynamic_prim_props in the class /iwbep/cl_v4_med_abs_strc_type only has "OpenSum" in the table 

add_dynamic_prim_props. 

However, when I let the full annotation, this table only has resolvedSum when it should have both properties openSum and resolvedSum

Therefore, as the backend only got one dynamic property, when the chart tries to process the property "openSum", it isn't found in the method /iwbep/if_v4_med_struc_ty_edm~get_primitive_property, resulting in an exception

 

I'm mentioning the experts @Andre_Fischer , @Ramjee_korada  ,@Marian_Zeis , @Jelena_Perfiljeva , @pulkit_bhatnagar , in case you could know or at least someone that could. 

Thank you!

entry.title: How to properly save/post in EWM table /SCWM/HUHDR given two custom fields
entry.content:
Hi, experts!

I have an EWM problem. Pretty new to this module, and like VIM it requires you to do a configuration before enabling development.
Anyway, my requirement asks me to do an append structure for two new fields (one Order Number (aufnr) and a BIN (/scwm/gmbin) in standard table /SCWM/HUHDR. I already did this via SE11 (it's an intrusive change, I know). And I get the data through implementation of badi interface /SCWM/IF_EX_DLV_GM_PROCESS. My only problem is I don't know the proper way to save/post this in the Handling Unit header table. There could be function modules or other helper classes available but I'm not aware yet.

I've been advised to use method Query of helper class /scwm/cl_dlv_management_prd to get HU data, but I need a way to save it in the table.

To replicate the steps, I just visit t-code /SCWM/MON, input the provided inbound delivery number in the Inbound Delivery node, selected the document and its line item, and then press Goods Receipt button, then the BAdI will be triggered. Then upon save, the GR column will have the value "Completed" from "Not Started".



My main question is: what's the best practice on saving data to custom fields in ewm tables (specifically HU Header)? Do we have function modules or classes available to do this? I appreciate the responses, thanks!

entry.title: Re: Transporting ESG data to SAP Sustainability Control Tower through Datasphere Integration
entry.content:
@Chris_Tam, thanks for this blog. I have a question regarding the following bit:

"The rest is simply following the UI to import, validate and publish the DSP data into SCT. So far, this import only supports new records and will warn of duplicate rows that are already in the SCT system. More info on this feature and it's limitations, can be found in the SCT help under the section 'Importing New Data from SAP Datasphere'."

entry.title: FM account assignment OPEX/C21600/13400000/- cannot be posted in ledger/year 9A/2026
entry.content:
FM account assignment OPEX/C21600/13400000/- cannot be posted in ledger/year 9A/2026

Message No. FMBS123

Diagnosis

The budget structure settings do not allow posting to the FM account assignment OPEX/C21600/13400000/-. The check of the budget structure ended for the combination of posting ledger and fiscal year 9A/2026 with the return code 4.

The system recognizes the following return codes for the check of posting addresses:

  • Return code 1:
    The option of check of posting addresses is check posting address list only or check both addresses (posting and derived budget addresses). However, FM account assignment OPEX/C21600/13400000/- is missing in the budget structure. Insert this account assignment in the budget structure for the combination of posting ledger and fiscal year 9A/2026.
  • Return code 2:
    The option of check of posting addresses is check derived budget address only or do not check addresses, but the validation of posting addresses does not allow posting on this address. Check the implementation of the Business Add-In (BAdI) Validate Budget and Posting Addresses in BS.
  • Return code 3:
    The FM account assignment OPEX/C21600/13400000/- leads to a conflict when you define a grouping key within the context of the budget structure. Check the implementation of the Business Add-In (BAdI) Define Grouping Key.
  • Return code 4:
    The derivation strategy used for deriving the budget address from the posting address derives an invalid budget address. You can use the program for displaying of budget structure settings to find out which derivation strategy is used. Check the Derivation Strategy for Budget Addresses in Customizing. This error may also be caused by inconsistent customizing of active FM account assignment elements in BCS and FM. This can be checked in IMG activity Activate Account Assignment Elements in Budget Control System.

System Response

Processing stops.

Procedure

Check the budget structure settings according to the given return code.

entry.title: RPT-1, Document AI, Perplexity in AI Core and co. - How to start your 2026 right with SAP's AI offer
entry.content:
AI remains years after its new wave of generative AI more omnipresent then ever in our daily lives and there not a single day passes where we don't talk about new announcements, AI ethics discussion, if it is a bubble, what amount of money is spent and so on. For those of you, who follow me, will know, that I preach all day that the key to successful AI adoption is a useful case, the right technology and working with the people.

Writing prompt guidelines is just enablement for another side-by-side tool and does not gain efficiency rather joy trying out new things. Building an agent for a pretty deterministic process might be fun and easy to implement, but expensive and unpredictable in production. And so on... While many are talking about large mainly American software vendors with their "agentic foundation killing any SaaS", SAP's offerings might not be so familiar to you (besides Joule and BDC) - so that's my motivation to provide a sneak peak of exciting topics in 2026.

Use Case: Onboarding of a new vehicle to the car fleet

In order to make tools tangible and understand the bigger picture, we will sketch an AI-assisted process of vehicle onboarding. Previously following steps were mandatory:

  1. Clerk typing vehicle data into system from the official vehicle document
  2. Vehicle Master Data Engineer adding additional information based on public search as required drivers licence and consumption values
  3. Finance expert to determine the tax amount to be paid for that year based on manual and local review
  4. Field Service Manager classifying the vehicle for the right purposes to be used

As you can see, this process is slow, very labor-intense and quite possibly error-prone. We will now step-by-step automate this by leveraging different AI tools offered by SAP within the Business AI portfolio üôÇ

Our ultimate goal is creating a low-code-first, enterprise-ready automation to avoid manual research and typing into the system:

 

Capturing of correct data: No more manual data entries from 2026 on

If you have in 2026 tasks which require typing in data from one medium (e.g. mail or paper) into your system, it's time to automate this asap. In our scenario, we do have the vehicle document on paper, as this one:

Instead of typing this, we use the SAP Start app on our iPhone to take a picture and the deep integration to SAP Document AI to process this document (see more here). We then utilise Document AI with our custom schema to extract the results and preview these to our clerk for a double-check. Instead of building entire new UIs, workflows, etc. we can now do this directly in Document AI and get a nice view of the document on the left and extraction on the right:

 

Automating web searching: Leverage the perplexity integration in SAP AI Core

SAP AI Core is the central hub for any access to MLOps activities and GenAI. With your BTP account you have access to a wide variety of partner models hosted on hyperscaler infrastructure and SAP's very own one with Mistral. If you didn't know this yet, that we have an orchestration workflow with prompt optimiser and much more, look up here which models we offer through your BTP contract.

Lately, we have added Perplexity as well - the AI-assisted search engine. Now we can connect publicly available data straight into our workflows, and it's huge, e.g.

  • classify the purchased non-catalog item to the correct product group
  • fill gaps in master data based on product sheets
  • make research on sustainability KPIs of your supplier
  • conduct analysis for B2G processes
  • get market macro trends or real-time insights, e.g. supply chain disruptions
  • ...

We will leverage the Perplexity integration to enhance our vehicle master data by the required drivers licence type for Swiss drivers licences and the energy consumption according to WLTP (an industry standard to measure consumption). We can model our prompt in SAP AI Launchpad and use the prompt registry to save it with placeholders:

And now it's so simple to add it to your pro-code app via CAP, to your low-code automation in SAP Build Process Automation or your integration flow in SAP Integration Suite:

In this iFlow you can see how we leverage the new outbound channel feature in Document AI to enrich the extraction of the results straightaway with an iFlow exposed via API management (for more, stay tuned on upcoming webinars). If you have seen in the previous screenshot of Document AI - there is a tab with "Z - additional values" üòâ

Do machine learning without data scientist: SAP's own foundational model RPT-1

Now we have been onboarding our vehicle, but we must classify for which tasks we can use it. Luckily we have already quite a large fleet and some data. Ideal for machine learning (yes that's also part of AI and yes AI is not only GenAI).

Machine learning learns from historical data - as simple as this is, this requires a data set, model fitting, model validation and deployment. Not straightforward. With Gemini, Le Chat and co. we are used to just prompt AI models. What if, we could just put a snapshot of our table to a pre-trained model and let it classify by itself. Congrats - you are now a RPT-1 user:

RPT-1 has its own playground, is accessible via AI Core and is phenomenal for transactional classification and prediction tasks. If you want to know more about its integration, I'd recommend you this gem. In my scenario, we use RPT-1 in our workflow in Build Process Automation to classify our vehicle correctly before we post it to our equipments in S/4HANA:

Performing more agentic tasks: Joule Studio

Previously you might have heard, you can use Joule Studio to make Joule truly yours. Joule Skills are intent-based automations made familiar to Joule to perform tasks conversational based. They can leverage workflows, pro-code and integrations via Integration Suite.

2025 Christmas gift, was the GA of the agent building capability in Joule where we can model agents. Agents are behaving non-deterministic and trying to mimic a human thought by providing it a scene and background - like an improvisation theatre. Now it's oftentimes pretty tricky to understand when an agent is really necessary. In our example we use an agent to determine how the vehicle tax are calculated for the Kanton St.Gallen, where we have registered our car and perform a calculation based on the perplexity web search (disclaimer - this can be modelled through a workflow in Build, it's just for the sake of simplicity):

 

Why choose SAP for your AI journey?

That's a good question and especially given there are soooo many tools on the market, why should you? It's simple: it's all about enterprise readiness. Behind every of this automation, there is only 5-10% AI, the remaining parts are security, audibility, traceability, transport management, scale resiliently in production, monitoring, low-code modelling etc. And for all of the remaining bits and pieces, SAP BTP has always been the best option from SAP Build to SAP Integration Suite. With SAP Document AI, we have a leader in document processing with inbound and outbound channels, and SAP AI Core a powerful AI orchestration service at low costs each.

While you can get other services cheaper somewhere, the TCO of this toolbox is imho astonishingly low. And for building this scenario from mobile device intake to equipment in S/4, I just needed a day to configure and build without pro-code needed. Happy AI-2026...

@Abdul_Waheed  : Actually in my case, the field names of root view and the db table are same for all fields so I had not given any mapping for any field in my BDEF and rest all the features are working fine.

Still I tried now giving the mapping but still the date field is getting saved as "blank"

define behavior for ZR_Sales_Header alias ZS_Header
persistent table zsales_header
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
early numbering
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;
  association _SalesOrdItem { create; }

  field ( readonly ) VBELN, ERDAT;

  //Dynamic Feature Control
  field( features : instance ) gbstk;

  //Validations
  validation ValidateCustomer on save { create; field kunnr; }
  validation ValidateSalesArea on save { create; field vkorg; field vtweg; field spart; }

  //Actions
  action (features : instance) ChangeStatus ; //result [1] $self;
  static action IncreasePrice;
  mapping for zsales_header
  {
   vbeln = vbeln;
   erdat = erdat;
   kunnr  = kunnr;
   auart  = auart;
   netwr  = netwr;
   waerk  = waerk;
   vkorg  = vkorg;
   vtweg  = vtweg;
   spart  = spart;
   gbstk  = gbstk;
  }
}
